As already mentioned, ultraviolet and infrared light are invisible to the human eye. However, astronomers can make color images from the light transmitted by ultraviolet or infrared filters by assigning a color to the image taken through these filters. Filters that transmit light over a range of wavelengths from ultraviolet to visible to infrared are used to investigate objects or areas of interest. Here are some examples:

Seeing through dust

Even though infrared wavelengths are invisible to the human eye, you can make color images from infrared light by assigning a color to the image taken through an infrared filter. The LSST Camera has three near-infrared filters: i, z, and y.

Near-infrared wavelengths of light are not as easily deflected by dust, unlike shorter visible wavelengths. Using these filters make it possible to see through some of the dust of a nebula, revealing hidden stars. These filters are also excellent for detecting very faint red stars, which give off more light in infrared wavelengths than in visible red light.

Let’s see how this works: The Trifid Nebula (M20) is a dense cloud of gas and dust. If the Trifid Nebula was observed using visible light alone, many of the stars within it would be hidden from view.

To make a full color image of the nebula, each of the filtered images had to be colorized, then combined. The u filter image was colorized blue, the g filter image was colorized green, and the y (infrared) filter image was colorized red. (There’s a particular reason that these colors are arranged in this order—more on this later.) Then the final full color image was color balanced.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Compare the three black and white images in Figure 9 of the Trifid Nebula, taken through g, r, and z filters. What differences in the brightness of the gas and dust, and stars, do you notice between the three images?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: What color do the stars that were previously hidden by dust appear to be in the full color image?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If only infrared filters are used (like the i, z, and y filters), would you be able to determine which stars are the ones hidden by the cloud of gas and dust? Explain your reasoning.
